evidence_span: the corrosion resistance of zirconium-base alloys compared with that of Zircaloy-4 ... was significantly improved by the reduction of the Sn content by $0 . 5 ~ \mathrm { w t } \%$ and by a small addition of Nb (about 0.05 to $0 . 2 \ \mathrm { w t } \%$ )
composition_raw: Sn reduction by 0.5 wt%; Nb: 0.05-0.2 wt%

evidence_span: the decrease in solute Sn atoms degraded mechanical properties such as ultimate tensile strength and $0 . 2 \%$ yield strength

evidence_span: The increase of the total content of Fe and Cr from 0.3 to $0 . 7 \mathrm { w t } \%$ improved the mechanical properties without affecting the corrosion resistance

evidence_span: Small additions of Mo and/or $\mathrm { V }$ resulted in a further improvement of mechanical properties

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk2
evidence_span: The uniform corrosion behavior of zirconium-base alloys (e.g., Zircaloy-4) has typically been characterized by a cubic time dependence at the first stage and by a nearly linear time dependence after achieving a weight gain of about 30 to $4 0 ~ \mathrm { m g / d m ^ { 2 } }$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk2
evidence_span: Typical weight gain versus time curves for three specimens tested in steam at $6 7 3 \ \mathrm { K }$ are given in Fig. 2.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk2
evidence_span: the corrosion curves of alloys with high corrosion resistance showed a cyclic behavior in posttransition regions.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk2
evidence_span: the relative corrosion resistance was evaluated by using the weight gains at 300 days as a measure of corrosion resistance.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk2
evidence_span: FIG. 3âWeight gains as a function of Nb content at 673 K for 300 days as a parameter of Sn content.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk2
evidence_span: Corrosion tests on Nb-free $Z \mathrm { r - l } . 0 5 \mathrm { n - 0 } . 2 \mathrm { F e - 0 } . 1 \mathrm { C r }$ and $Z \mathrm { r } { - } 1 . 5 \mathrm { S n }$ $0 . 2 \mathrm { F e - } 0 . 1 \mathrm { C r }$ alloys were abandoned in 120 days because of the heavy corrosion.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk2
evidence_span: Small additions (0.05 to $0 . 2 \%$ ) of $\mathrm { N b }$ reduced the weight gains to a significant extent

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk2
evidence_span: further additions of more than about $0 . 2 \%$ lead to an increase in weight gain.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk2
evidence_span: With decreasing Sn content, weight gains generally decreased (i.e.. corrosion resistances increased).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_025_chunk2
evidence_span: Thus the corrosion resistance of zirconium-base alloys, especially Zircaloy-4. could be significantly improved by the reduction of the Sn content to $0 . 5 \%$ and a small addition of $\mathbf { N b }$ (about 0.05 to $0 . 2 \%$ ).
